snippet: Judges who were told that a defendant in a hypothetical case was genetically predisposed to violence imposed lighter sentences than they otherwise would have, researchers reported.
abstract: Research finds that judges who learned that a convicted assailant was genetically predisposed to violence imposed lighter sentences in a hypothetical case than they otherwise would have; study, the most rigorous to date on how behavioral biology can sway judicial decisions, appears in journal Science.
lead_paragraph: Judges who were told that a defendant in a hypothetical case was genetically predisposed to violence imposed lighter sentences than they otherwise would have, researchers reported.

headline.seo: Brain Evidence Sways Sentencing in Study of Judges
headline.main: Study of Judges Finds Evidence From Brain Scans Led to Lighter Sentences
